text:
209-205 Bleecker Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Minetta Street (left), opposite the northern end of Hancock Street (future Sixth Avenue Extension). At exactly this point, which is at the old line between the Herring Farm on the west and the West Bayard Farm on the east, is the western end of that section of the present Bleecker Street which was originally David Street, laid out east from here to Broadway.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Minetta Street, east side, north of Bleecker Street. About 1922.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

Sixth Avenue-Extension, south from Bleecker Street, showing the slice-through that eliminated Hancock Street from Manhattan maps. Under construction is the Municipal subway. The center foreground was the former site of the R. C. Church of Our Lady of Pompeii (St. Carlos Missionary Fathers). On the left are several six story apartment houses, that formerly bore No's. 1-3, 5-7 and 9-13 Hancock Street. These will remain, acquiring 6th Avenue identities. On the extreme right is the rear of the Downing Street site, upon which in 1941 will rise a modern apartment structure, No. 10 Downing Street. The new west line of the Avenue will run there, forming the easterly side of this building plot. The partially demolished 6-story structures shown there front on West Houston Street. They will remain. Through the center is Congress Street, a short thoroughfare extending south of West Houston to King Street. This is to be included in the new thoroughfare.

P. L. Sperr

May 12, 1927
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

text:
2-8 Minetta Street, west side, north from Bleecker Street. Buildings shown, are frame houses with brick fronts. Note demolition at this point for the Sixth Ave. Extension.

October 14, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

Dipping Tar for Subway work-- East side of Sixth Avenue, south of Bleecker Street.
October 11, 1928.
P.L.Sperr, photographer.

title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

text:
Sixth Avenue, north from Bleecker Street, showing the Sixth Avenue "El" bend at W. 3rd Street. Carmine Street is at the left and Minetta Lane at the right. View 2 is limited to the Minetta Lane to W. 3rd Street frontage. This was developed as a play area in 1938. The old type houses shown are No's. 136 and 138 W. 3rd Street. Above same is the distinctive apartment house, No. 1 Fifth Avenue.

March 25, 1933
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.

text:
Minetta Street, nos. 2,4,6, Manhattan

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York]
Code I A-3
Nov. 21, 1935

p.106, Changing New York

2-4-6 Minetta Street, west side, between Sixth Avenue and Minetta Lane, built between 1800 and 1807, probably the homes of artisans excluded from the then fashionable Varick Street. Occupied by ragpickers in early 1900s. Restored in 1913. Nos. 2 and 6 were remodelled in 1924. Demolished in 1936.

Sixth Ave., north from Minetta Street (right) and showing empty lots lining the east side of same. These were left when this southern extension of the Ave. was projected. The Sixth Ave. Elevated is seen making an eastward turn on West 3rd Street. In the distance appears the Empire State Building. This set of 3 views shows details of the same area.

September 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

September 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Minetta apts.

text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from Minetta Street, showing grassy plots upon which were buildings prior to the extension of Sixth Ave., from Minetta Lane south to Church Street. The elongated 3-story structure on the right, that apparently faces Sixth Ave. is No. 2 Minetta Lane. Minetta Place, an enclosed Court in the center of this block formerly was in the foreground; the northern extremity of which is shown enclosed by a fence in views 2 and 3.

September 18, 1937:

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Minetta Street. Minetta Place, an enclosed Court in the center of this block formerly was in the foreground; the northern extremity of which is shown enclosed by a fence in views 2 (middle) and 3 (right).

text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, between Minetta Street and Minetta Lane, showing in the open foreground area the site of the garden court, Minetta Place. Extension of the Avenue and related demolition caused this Greenwich Village feature of yore to disappear. Shortly two modern apartment houses will rise here. One to the right and one to the left of the dwellings, the rears of which are in the center. Incidently, these will remain, facing as they do, on Minetta Street. The tenement at the right is on the opposite side of this street.

About 1939

Alexander Alland, photo

Sixth Avenue, east side, north from Bleecker Street, showing that odd corner formed by Minetta Street (right) and Minetta Lane (left). Nestling here was the former Minetta Place. This would be about where the tool shacks appear. Most of the buildings are gOne, though two remain, No's. 20 and 22 Minetta Street. The vacant space to the left of these is to be the site of a new 6-story apartment house according to the New York Times of December 16, 1939. Across this cleared site are buildings on the north side of Minetta Lane. Towering above are apartments on Washington Square. Behind the sign board on the right is the peculiar bend in Minetta Street.
April 13, 1940
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
(3)
A southeastward view towards Minetta Lane (center) showing the aforementioned apartment house completed. West 3rd Street is on the left and does not appear. To the right is Minetta Street flowing into 6th Avenue at Bleecker Street. The latter is not
included.
August 3, 1940
P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Bleecker Street.
